docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton missed the first public meeting of the President's Health Care Task Force, which she leads, to remain today at the bedside of her ill father, Hugh Rodham. Mr. Rodham, 81, who suffered a stroke on March 19, remained in critical condition at St. Vincent Infirmary Medical Center here.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's official. Hillary Rodham Clinton will not bake cookies, keep to the East Wing or stand quietly by her man. No, she will stand with her man, or maybe ahead of him, in formulating health care policy. It's a genuine job and an unusual arrangement, but it is who the Clintons are. In that regard, it is also more honest than the charade they went through before her independence became a campaign liability and Mrs. Clinton helped get her husband elected by pretending to be what she was not.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mrs. Clinton spoke after Senator Bernie Sanders defeated her in the New Hampshire presidential primary on Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democrats may have strayed off the high road, but they’re a long way from Trump-Cruz territory.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column previews upcoming Democratic presidential debate; notes race has become more competitive between Sen Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton, resulting in somewhat negative turn for campaign.
docs.snippet: The Democrats may have strayed off the high road, but they’re a long way from Trump-Cruz territory....

docs.lead_paragraph: She’s like family to us all, right? Well, let’s give them something to talk about.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column notes that there is universal public fascination with Hillary Rodham Clinton, both in terms of positive and negative attention; asserts that Clinton may be one of last all-purpose celebrities in era of increasingly fractured attentions; suggests that interest in Clinton will shift from her personal life to her work only if she is elected president.
docs.snippet: She’s like family to us all, right? Well, let’s give them something to talk about....

docs.lead_paragraph: It would have been the natural thing for Barack Obama, only hours after his emotional embrace by the Kennedys, to greet the rebuffed Hillary Clinton at the State of the Union address.

docs.lead_paragraph: She already made an appearance this week on "Meet the Press." And she can't very well do "Oprah."
docs.abstract: And from the excerpts sent out by the Clinton campaign, we can see that Mrs. Clinton isn't only running to be the first female president; she's running to be the first grrrl.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Kleiman, a professor of public policy at the University of California-Los Angeles, is outraged that Hillary Clinton failed to unequivocally rule out interrogation tactics "that aren't technically torture" in an interview published by The Washington Post on Wednesday.
docs.abstract: Mark Kleiman, a professor of public policy at the University of California-Los Angeles, is outraged that Hillary Clinton failed to unequivocally rule out interrogation tactics "that aren't technically torture" in an interview published by The Washington Post on Wednesday. docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton told a group of gay elected officials last night that she would support a gay marriage law in New York if a future governor and legislature chose to enact one, according to three participants at the meeting.
docs.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton told a group of gay elected officials last night that she would support a gay marriage law in New York if a future governor and legislature chose to enact one, according to three participants at the meeting. Mrs. Clinton listened and spoke for more than an hour with the three-dozen officials [...]
